message.raw:
When user marks deleted/inaccessible shot as not done, check if the file exists
and unmark it as deleted if it does exist. This allows for recovery in the case
of a network glitch or similar making a network drive temporarily unavailable,
or when the user deleted, but then restored, a shot file.

message.raw:
Make lyse handle gracefully shot files that have been deleted off disk.

Whenever lyse tries to read a HDF5 file that has been deleted, it
previously would crash. Now, the shot's row
in the filebox is marked with an icon showing it as deleted off disk
and a warning is printed. No more singleshot analysis will be run on that shot
file, but its data will be kept in the dataframe until the user removes it
from the filebox, and thus still be available for multishot analysis.

The use case for this is when an experiment is cycling just to 'keep warm' or
whatever, and shots are being deleted so as not to consume hard drive space.

I removed some of the unused optional ways of calling some of lyse's
internal methods so as to decrease the number of places where
lyse reads a HDF5 file. Previously multiple code paths were allowed - one
which was a bit cleaner (reading HDF5 files at the last minute)
 and one which was a performance optimisation (read them in advance, outside the
 GUI thread, and pass the results to the GUI-related methods). Now only
the performant way of calling these methods is allowed - which is what all
the calling code was using anyway.

message.raw:
Replaced call of depreciated pandas sort() function with sort_index() to ensure forwards compatibility with pandas.
Sort has been removed as of pandas 0.20.
Note that there are still incompatabilities with pandas 0.20 in lyse, so I've set it to check that the version is less than this.

message.raw:
FIxed bugs in and made more robust the copying to clipboard functionality.
The figure is saved to disk and then a subprocess is used to copy it to
the clipboard, and the subprocess keeps running until the clipboard is
overwritten, so that pasting works on setups which require the program to provide
the paste data at paste time (and thus require them to keep running). Cough
Xorg, cough.

This might sound like overkill, but It's much cleaner. The subprocess can have
its own QApplication to handle the clipboard actions, and thus doesn't
interfere with the parent's QApplication, and doesn't require it to have one,
if matplotlib is using a different backend (even the Qt backend could be qt 4 or
qt 5 at the moment, so we don't want to have to deal with this). I found
difficult to debug breakage when trying to make this work when a QApplication
already existed, so a clean break is much nicer, and is required to keep the
clipboard data around (on linux anyway) once the copying program has closed.

I've made the subprocess code forward compatible with PyQt5.

This functionality requires a function I added to zprocess 2.2, so I added
a check_version call for this.

message.raw:
Added "copy to clipboard" functionality for plots. An image can be copied to
the clipboard by clicking a button in the plot window, or by ctrl-c/cmd-c when
the plot window has focus.

Copying can also be done programatically like:

    from lyse.analysis_subprocess import copy_figure_to_clipboard
    copy_figure_to_clipboard(fig)

however the copying will not occur immediately - only once control is returned
to the Qt mainloop. I have not put this functionality (of copying
programatically) in a more accessible place as it is not very general - it
requires a Qt mainloop to be running.

message.raw:
Added integer row labels to FileBox. This makes it possible to quickly find
a shot in the Filebox if you know its index in the dataframe, which may be
easier to get than the filepath or similar, since by the time a shot becomes
a datapoint in a plot it may only be recognisable by its index.

message.raw:
Fixed a regression, delete buttons did not prompt for confirmation.

PyQt is too clever for its own good and inspects the argument list of slots,
calling them differently depending on how many arguments they take. We added a
"confirm=True" keyword argument to on_delete_selection slots, and thereafter
PyQt decided to call QAction.triggered with an extra boolean positional argument
for whether a QAction is checked - even though these ones were not checkable.
This was interpreted of course as "confirm=False" and the deletions didn't
prompt for confirmation.

This has been fixed by splitting the slots off  into separate stub methods that
takes no arguments and just call the underlying delete_selection() methods.

message.raw:
Fixed bug in which columns no longer present in the dataframe (due to removing
shots) were not removed from the Qt model.

This entailed changing DataFrameModel.update_row() and EditColumns.update_columns()

DataFrameModel.update_row() was modified to detect when the
Qt model has columns no longer present in the dataframe (this is the part
of the code where *new* columns are detected, as well). Defunct columns in the
Qt model are deleted and a few dictionaries are updated to reflect the new
numbering of columns.

Updated the conditional emission of the signal DataFrameModel.columns_changed()
at the end of this method. Previously only emitted when new columns were added,
is now emitted when columns were deleted as well

The only slot connected to this signal is FileBox.on_columns_changed(),
which calls EditColumns.update_columns() with some of the updated dictionaries
(EditColumns is the GUI for selecting which columns to show in the FileBox).

EditColumns.update_columns() has therefore been modified to correctly handle
the fact that the new dictionaries may have had columns removed, and not just
added as was previously the case.

message.raw:
Added an object lyse.persistent_storage

"An empty object that analysis routines can store data in. It will
persist from one run of an analysis routine to the next when the routine
is being run from within lyse. No attempt is made to store data to disk,
so if the routine is run multiple times from the command line instead of
from lyse, or the lyse analysis subprocess is restarted, data will not be
retained. An alternate method should be used to store data if desired in
these cases"

message.raw:
Fixes #17 by speeding up dataframe transfers.

Moved call to df.convert_objects to the lyse server, which makes dataframes more
efficiently picklable by replacing columns containing only a single array datatype
with an array of that datatype. Previously df.convert_obects was only called
after the transfer, so the preceding pickling was slow.

For the large, mostly numeric dataframe tested, this speeds
up pickling and unpickling by approx a factor of 5.

Also set convert_numeric=False in the call to df.convert_objects. It was
previously set to True, but I don't think this is what we want. With it False,
all-numeric columns are still converted as desired. With it True, *strings* are
converted to numbers even if only a single string is convertible to a numeric
value, with all non-convertable values in the column becoming NaNs. I don't
think this is what we want. If the user asked for a string, the data should
remain a string. It is presumptuous to assume otherwise and I suspect a
misunderstanding by whoever wrote this line originally.

message.raw:
Fixes #16, routines not reordering correctly with GUI buttons.

Problem was confusing a passive transformation with an active transformation:

passive transformation: constructing a new list from a list of indices saying
where in the old list each item should come from (what we were doing)

active transformation: constructing a new list out of a list of indices for
where in the new list items in the old list should be moved to (what we should
have been doing)

When a single routine was moved, this simply swapped it with the one above or
below it and so a passive and active transformation of the order are identical.
But for reordering multiple routines at once it gave the wrong result.

Fixes #16, routines not reordering correctly with GUI buttons.

Problem was confusing a passive transformation with an active transformation:

passive transformation: constructing a new list from a list of indices saying
where in the old list each item should come from (what we were doing)

active transformation: constructing a new list out of a list of indices for
where in the new list items in the old list should be moved to (what we should
have been doing)

When a single routine was moved, this simply swapped it with the one above or
below it and so a passive and active transformation of the order are identical.
But for reordering multiple routines at once it gave the wrong result.

values.message:
Fixes #16, routines not reordering correctly with GUI buttons.

Problem was confusing a passive transformation with an active transformation:

passive transformation: constructing a new list from a list of indices saying
where in the old list each item should come from (what we were doing)

active transformation: constructing a new list out of a list of indices for
where in the new list items in the old list should be moved to (what we should
have been doing)

When a single routine was moved, this simply swapped it with the one above or
below it and so a passive and active transformation of the order are identical.
But for reordering multiple routines at once it gave the wrong result.

message.raw:
Removed plot options column which never did anything anyway, and now that
plots re-show themselves each run after you close a window, seems less
necessary.

I can't really think of what plot options would do anymore except
show and hide specific plots, but now I'm thinking that's not the right place
for that configuration. Users can for now comment out plot lines in code, and
if we end up with an analysis globals system then users can set globals there
that their code can check before deciding whether to show a plot or whatnot.

message.raw:
DataFrame index rename [('sequence', '', '', ''), ('run time', '', '', '')] to
['sequence', 'run time']. It used to be the latter, before 39aabd2 when the
df.set_index call was changed to spcify the columns with padded tuples.
The concomitant change to df.index.names broke user space analysis code, namely
the df.sequences monkey patch, that calls df.index.get_level_values('sequence').
The monkey patched sequence method could instead use:
df.index.get_level_values(df.index.names[0]), but there's no need for the padded
names anyway.
